response.answer_text: As pointed out, there is no way to really know. So 100–400 billion is the common estimate. The interesting part of the questions is why. And then you can only see the ones that are fairly near. The estimate on Red Dwarfs ranges from 60–70% of all stars. But that is also a flexible situation. 70% of all the luminent stars, those that are the size of our Sun or larger and shine brightly in the night sky, are located in the center bulge of the galaxy.
